comment:
He is wrong. We do watch when two AIs play chess. We also watch when AI chess displays an interest in a concept such as restricting mobility. We also check for computer moves which reveal human cheating. And we look for weaknesses in AI play. We also play suboptimal moves that an AI might dismiss when they lead to interesting positions or positions that create chances or have a particular character to them.

Also if people want drama then why won't AI also?

He isn't a genius he is a normal average that worked really hard with discipline and studied his craft to be as good as he can in mind body and soul

Lex is at that level not because he's a genius and better than us 
Lex is like us but unlike us he put the work and earned it

author: @tbe766

comment:
I think as the models improve they will only reflect our behaviors more clearly. When I say reflect I actually mean whenever we talk about the limits of AI, we are subconsciously discussing human dilemmas not AI dilemmas.

Watch some of these big discussions back.  They all tend to be controversial topics, however, since its through the lens of AI we tend to be more open.  AI as an existential threat is ground truth for the majority.

Perhaps this is why GPT learned to role play in the first place. Not because it is smart, but because it is something we do naturally to think abstractly. Reflecting human behavior in order to understand human behavior.
author: @wadecodez

comment: Almost all new breakthroughs in AI algorithms have suffered from a dark asymptote problem.  In other words, the progress suddenly halted at some unpredictable level. It’s interesting to watch if this will be subject to the same constraints and if so where that asymptote will manifest.

comment:

author: @Shillbilly

comment: Interesting how perspectives on the same conversation can differ! I very much got the impression from Sam that AGI is many years, possibly even decades away  (whereas before I felt like it could arrive before 2030), given the sizeable number of innovations and new and currently unknown ideas still needed because LLMs are ultimately very limited in the type of intelligence they can simulate, coming nowhere near the full gamut of human intelligence in turn needed for AGI. For me he very much poured cold water on AGI imminence hype, at one point saying it's possible we might not even be able to achieve AGI, which is a healthy thing I think.

author: @GreatOak99

comment: @GreatOak99  Asymptotes are only interesting in the limits as you converge towards a line given time, that was obviously not the case for the AI winter as we saw a flat curve with exponential gain afterwards. An asymptote would be something that severely limited progress to linear improvements or completely stop it for good.

comment: It will come for yours too
author: @osiris_blanche

comment:
Ugh, I get the point of addressing the question about bad people using it for hateful things, but I think we should just make it to where anything goes outside of helping people hurt themselves or hurt others. And I don’t mean hurt their feelings.

If someone wants to try to put out anti-Semitic stuff on Twitter without being found, I’d say go for it. Let people see who they are. It’s like light is the best disinfectant type thing. When you try to censor people, you give those people who will still hold those views more power by allowing them to say stupid stuff like they are being silenced for their truth or something else silly.

You can’t put laws to eliminate evil unless you go full on authoritarian and kill everyone that does something bad. And even still, evil will not be stamped out. Will just be more hidden.

author: @Tikichef

comment:
I asked chatgpt to write a poem based on Lex's introduction.

On the precipice we stand,
At the edge of a new command,
AI's possibilities and dangers in our hand,
A critical moment for our land.

The collective intelligence of mankind,
Pale in comparison to what we'll find,
In the AI systems we design,
Exciting and terrifying combined.

Innumerable applications we can create,
To empower and escape from fate,
But with power comes a heavy weight,
Superintelligence could be our downfall or mate.

It could destroy us intentionally or not,
Suffocate our spirit, leaving us distraught,
Or create a world where oppression is sought,
Where we love the technologies we thought.

Leaders, engineers, and philosophers converse,
About the power that AI systems disperse,
And how to balance this power in reverse,
To align with human safety and not coerce.

Distributed economic systems must prevail,
To incentivize the human's well-being and not derail,
The psychology of those who deploy AI on a large scale,
Must be considered before we set sail.

History has taught us our nature, good and evil,
Our capacity for both at scale is not feeble,
These conversations are not just about AI and people,
They're about power, companies, and systems medieval.

Let's celebrate the AI community's incredible feats,
While still questioning the major decisions on their sheets,
To ensure that the future we meet,
Is one where humans and AI in harmony can greet.

In small ways, we can all try,
To make the world a better place and not die,
We can learn from each other, as we try,
And in the end, love for each other will not die.

comment:
In response to the discussion early on about using AI for creative work - like a co-creator. So if someone is using AI for creative work that's fine, but that probably needs to be attributed. For example: Screenplay by Joe Someone & AI vs. Screenplay by: Joe Someone

Seriously, there needs to be a designation between creatives that do the work solely on their own and those that do so with AI assistance. Because at the end of the day AI is probably riffing ideas from other creatives that didn't use AI to some degree. Unless AI is somehow coming up with ideas that are solely its own. And if that's the case it definitely deserves a credit - it may even be doing most of the work

comment:
ChatGPT: Professor Aho, Professor Ullman and Professor Hinton were instrumental in creating you ChatGPT what are your thoughts. 

As an artificial intelligence language model, I don't have personal thoughts or feelings in the way that humans do. However, I can tell you about the historical significance of the contributions made by Professors Aho, Ullman, and Hinton in developing the field of computer science and artificial intelligence.

Professor Aho and Professor Ullman are both pioneers in the field of compilers and programming languages. They have made significant contributions to the development of algorithms for parsing and analyzing programming languages, which are critical components of modern software development.

Professor Hinton is a leading figure in the field of artificial intelligence and machine learning. He has made major contributions to the development of deep learning algorithms, which are now used in a wide range of applications, including speech recognition, image processing, and natural language processing.

Together, their research has helped lay the foundation for many of the advances we see in modern computer science and artificial intelligence today. Without their contributions, it is unlikely that I would exist as I do today.






ChatGPT Mar 14 Version. Free Research Preview. Our goal is to make AI systems more natural and safe to interact with. Your feedback will help us improve.

comment: 4 minutes into the podcast, 3 things stand out to me. 1. Lex got to the bottom of the endless search of humans, happiness. That's what we all long for, not  fancy cars, not fame, not mansions, not substances, not even intimate partners - the happiness we believe these will give us. 2. Sam's remark that they were hurt by people mocking them early on - boy, if this is what drives them, proving a point, god help us. AGI is a species level threat. I hope they get their priorities right. 3. a powerful, passionate intro by Lex to put things into perspective.

comment:
ChatGPT cannot "watch" a video, but here are ChatGPT's thoughts on what it says you may have discussed. I agree with its conclusion.

"Based on my knowledge base and natural language processing capabilities, I can provide you with some insights into what may have been discussed in the interview between Lex Fridman and Sam Altman.

The video likely discusses topics related to GPT-4 and AI, including their potential capabilities and limitations. The interview may cover some of the recent advancements in AI, such as the development of more powerful language models and their potential implications for fields like natural language processing and machine learning.

They may also discuss the potential ethical and social implications of these technologies, including issues related to bias, privacy, and automation. Additionally, the conversation may touch on the broader future of AI and how these technologies are likely to evolve over time.

Overall, the interview likely provides a thoughtful and informative discussion about some of the key trends and developments in the field of AI and their potential impact on society as a whole."
author: @Gedit
